projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: The Infallible Guide TO TRAVELLERS, OR Direct Independants.

Giving a moſt Exact Account of the four Principal Roads of England, beginning at the Standard in Cornhill, and extending to the Sea-Shore, and Branching to moſt of the Cities, Corporations, and Market-Towns in England and Wales, with their true diſtance of Miles and Furlongs, according to Mr. Oglesby's Dimenſuration.
LONDON, Printed for T. B. and are to be ſold by moſt Bookſellers. 1682.

figure.p: Expreſt in ye Mapp by a Black Line Independants.
Expreſt by a Prickt Line Principal croſs Roads.

div.head: Iter I. The Road from LONDON to ABERISTWITH, On the Sea-Coaſt in Cardiganſhire, South-Wales.

2. The Direct Horizontal Diſtance
3. The Vulgar Computation
4. The Dimenſuration

Comp.

div.p:
With the Branch to OXFORD, Thus:
From LONDON
Comp. Meaſure.
to Tetſworth 37 37 44′ 6 44′ 6
Wheatley 05 42 05′ 4 50′ 2
OXFORD
05 47 05′ 4 55′ 6
Counties Including the Road, are Midleſex, Buckinghamſhire, Oxfordſhire, Gloceſterſhire, Worceſterſhire, Herefordſhire, Radnorſhire and Cardiganſhire.
Rivers croſt Over, are the Brent, Coln, Tame, Charwel, Avon, Severn, Teme, Lug, Ithon, Wye, Iſtwith and Rydal.

row.cell: M. F.
At the Pound in St. Giles's LONDON, the forward Way on the Right to Hampſted.
One Mile 3 Furl. beyond Ʋxbridg, the Right to Alesbury.
A little ſhort of Weſt-Wickham, the forward Way on the Right.
At the end of Weſt-Wickham, the Coach Way to Stoken-Church on the Right.
A Furl. beyond Wheatley Bridg, the forward Way on the Left to OXFORD.
A Furl. beyond Forreſt Hill, the Left to OXFORD.
Six Furlongs beyond Stanton St. John Church, the Right to Odington.
Two furl. beyond Weſton Church, the Right to Barton.
A Mile ſhort of Chapel on the Heath, the forward Way on the Left to Chipping-Norton.
At the top of the Hill, 2 Furl. beyond Little Rolwright Church, the forward Way on the Right to Long Gompton.
At the 4 Shire Stone, the Right to Campden.
Two Furl. beyond Broadway, the Left to Somerfield.
Six Furl. ſhort of Wickenford Bridg, the Left to Hinton.
Two Furl. ſhort of Perſhore, the Left to Cheltenham.
At the end of Perſhore, the Right to Aulceſter.
The Left to Ʋpton.
At the entering Stouton, the Left to Ʋpton, the Right to Eaſton White-Lady.
Entering Bromyard Heath, the Right to Edwin.
Entring Bromyard, the Left to HEREFORD.
A Mile beyond Bromyard, the Left to Weobley.
A Furl. beyond Lemſter, the Left to Weobley.
Nine Furl. ſhort of Kingſland Church, the forward Way on the Left to Keinton.
At the end of Kingſland, the Right to Knighton.
At the end of Eaſterton, the Left to Hoobden.
Five Furl. beyond Preſtain, the Right to Knighton.
Two Furl. beyond Comaron Fluv, the Right-Hand Way.
Between the Rivers Ithon and Clowedok, the Left to Garthuagh.
Six Furl. beyond Dulas Fluv. the Right to St. Harmon.
Two Furl. beyond Riadergowy, the Left to Llanimdoffry.
Where firſt appears the River Eland, the Left to Roſefair.
The Left to Cardigan.
The Left to Llanruſted.
In Llanbadern-vaur, the L. to Llanruſted
M. F.

THe Standard in Cornhil LONDON: Whence your Courſe being Weſt, you proceed along Cornhil, the Poultry, Cheapſide, Blowbladder-Street and Newgate-Street, through Newgate and along Snow-Hill and Holborn.
The Pound in St. Giles's where you bear to the Left.
You leave the Town.

The Lord Mayor's Banqueting-Houſe on the Right, where the Lord Mayor of the
City of LONDON Riding to View the Conduit-Heads, is annually Treated.

Begins Hide-Park Wall on the Left, continuing 9 Furl. a little beyond and at the Iſſuing out of the Way to Padington ſtands Tyburn, the Common Place of Execution of Malefactors for the Cities of LONDON and WESTMINSTER, and County of Midleſex.
Enter Kenſington Gravel-Pits, a diſcontinued Village of 4 Furlongs.
You paſs through Shepperd's Buſh, a ſmall Village.
Enter Acton of near 3 Furl. a Village of ſome Accomodation.
Enter Hanwel, a ſmall Village ſeated on the River Brent.
Enter Norcoat, another ſmall Village of about 2 Furlongs.
Leave Hays Church on the Left 2 Furl.
Enter Hays, a Village of 2 Furlongs, from the end of which, Hellingdon Heath continues, till.
You enter Hellingdon, a ſmall Village.
Enter Ʋxbridg of a Mile in Length, a large, well frequented and Accomodated Market Town; at the End of which you croſs the Coln and Enter Buckinghamſhire.
You have Hedgley Park on the Left.
You Deſcend gently for 4 Furl.
You Enter a Wood of a Mile upon the Road.

Enter Beconsfield of 2 Furlongs, a reaſonable
well Accomodated Market-Town.
You come to a Woody Deſcent of 4 F.
Loudwater a ſmall Village contiguous on the Left.
Enter High Wickham of 3 Furl. Extent, ſeated in a pleaſant Vale; a large, well built and frequented Corporation, Market and Mayor Town; Electing Burgeſſes to Parliament, &c.
Enter Weſt Wickham a Village of 2 Furl. and ſome Reception.
You Aſcend for half a Mile, your Road being Woody on each Hand and continuing ſo to 38 Miles.
Enter Oxfordſhire.
You come to Stoken-Church, a ſmall but well known Through-fare.
You Deſcend for 6 Furl. your Road being Woody on your Left.
Enter Tetſworth of 2 Furl. Length, a well Accomodated Village; whence you have a very direct Way to Wheatley.
You come to Wheatley Bridg, being a fair Stone-bridg of 8 Arches over the River Tame.
Here your Road turning ſhort upon the Right, and the direct or forward Way leading to OXFORD, you proſecute the latter: and
Enter Wheatley, an indifferent good Town of 3 Furlongs length.
Croſſing a ſmall Brook you Aſcend for 2 Furlongs.
You Deſcend gently for 10 Furlongs, croſſing a ſmall Rill in the bottom.
You Deſcend again for 4. Furlongs.

You croſs the fair River Charwel, which riſing in Northamptonſhire, paſſes by Banbury, and a little below this place unites with the Thames; receiving into it, 1ſt. the Culen, 2ly. the Come, 3ly. the Tude, and therein the Ornus, Sotbrook and Oke, 4ly. the Swere, and laſtly the Reie or Bure.

You actually Enter the Famous City and Univerſity of OXFORD, pleaſantly ſeated at the Conflux of the Charwel with the Thames or Iſis: A place of great Antiquity, large, ſtrong and well-built; and adorn'd with 16 Colleges and 8 Halls, ſhewing a curious Library, a ſtately Theater and large Cathedral; beſides 14 Pariſh Churches: Is Govern'd by a Mayor, &c. Keeps Courts for all Actions, Elects 4 Burgeſſes to Parliament, has 2 Markets Weekly; Honor'd in its Noble Chancellor James Duke of Ormond, and in giving Title to the Right Honorable Aubery Vere Earl of OXFORD; in a word, for its ſtately Schools, Theater and Library, Beautiful Colleges and Halls, Liberal Endowments and plentiful Salaries, for Number of Students and Excellent Oeconomy, the Chriſtian World affords not its Parallel.
But to proceed.
You bear ſhort on the Right, as aforeſaid.
Foreſt Hill, a ſmall Vill. contiguous on the Right only.
Stanton, St. John's Church on the Right a Furlong.
Begin a Wood on the Right for 4 Furl.
You croſs a Rill over a Stone-bridg, and 2 Furl. farther another.
Enter Iſlip Common continuing almoſt to the Town.
Over a Stone-bridg of 6 Arches you croſs the Reie or Bure.
Here you Enter Iſlip of a Furlong in length, a ſmall but well Accomodated Town for Reception of Travellers.
Enter Blechingdon, a Village of 2 Furl. length.
Over a Wooden-bridg you croſs the forementioned Charwel. Pag. 7
The Right-Hand Way unites again at 64′ 5. but is leſs frequented: The Left-Hand Ways hereabouts leads to that pleaſantly ſituate Corporation and Market Town, Woodſtock about 2 Miles diſtant.
Wotton Church appears 2 Furlongs on the Left.
You come to Glimton a ſmall Village, the Left-Hand Ways ſtill leading to Woodſtock aforeſaid; and here you are equally diſtant from LONDON and WORCESTER.
You have Piddington Church 3 Furl. to the Right.
You come to Enſton, a ſmall Village of about a Furlong long, yet of good Reception: Whence for 3 Miles together your Road is ſtraight and direct.
The forward Way on the Left is the direct Road to Chipping-Norton, a large (though not compact) Corporation and Market-Town, about a Mile and half diſtant.
You have a Houſe contiguous on the Right call'd Chapel on the Heath.
Chipping-Norton lies at Right Angles on the Left about 6 Furlongs diſtant.
You Deſcend 7 Furl. Aſcending 5 Furl.

Little Rolwright Church lies 3 Furlongs on the Left, in which Pariſh about a Mile on the Right ſtands that Circular Monument of great Stones; ſaid to be Erected in Memory of a Battel there fought by Rollo the Dane.
Begins a Hedg on the Right continuing 3 Furlongs, ſeperating the Counties of Oxford and Warwick.
Little Compton Church appears 2 Furl. on the Left.
You Deſcend 4 Furlongs, and ſtill paſſing between the ſaid Counties.
You come to the 4 Shire Stone, the well known Limits of Warwickſhire, Oxfordſhire, Worceſterſhire and Gloceſterſhire, which laſt you here Enter.

You croſs the Evenlode which riſing about a Mile higher, Embraces the Iſis a bove OXFORD; and here preſently you Enter Morton in the Marſh, Vulgo Morton Henmarſh, of 2 Furlongs; ſeated on the Foſs-way, a good Through-fare, though no Market-Town as formerly.
You Aſcend Broadway Hills for 5 Furl.
Enter Burton on the Hill, a well Inhabited Village of 2 Furl.
Burtons-Aſh on the Left yielding a very fair Proſpect.
You have a Direction Hand in the Road at the croſs Way to Winchcomb on the Left, and Campden & Blockley on the Right.
You Deſcend Broadway Hills aforeſaid, the Deſcent continuing to the Town.
Enter Broadway, a well-built and well Accomodated Town of 5 Furl. Extent.
Childs Wickham Church 2 Furlongs on the Left.
Over a Stone-bridg call'd Wickenford Bridg, you croſs a Brook and Enter Worceſterſhire; and a little after the fertile Vale of Eveſholm.

Over a Stone-bridg of 6 great and ſeveral ſmall Arches you croſs the fair River Avon and Enter Perſhore, 7 Furlongs in length; a Town of good Antiquity, large and well frequented, containing 2 Pariſh Churches, and Enjoying 2 Markets Weekly.

You have Alesborough an Antient Houſe
on the Left, giving the Title of Baron to the Right Honorable the Lord Coventry.
Enter Stouton a ſmall Village of about a Furlong; whence you have a direct Way even to WORCESTER.

You Enter the Suburbs, and 3 Furlongs farther through Sudbury Gate, the City of WORCESTER; a City and County of it ſelf, Pleaſantly and Commodiouſly ſeated on the Severn: Of great Antiquity, and Enjoying divers Privileges and Immunities, and though a plentiful Sufferer in Calamities, &c. yet ſtill remains a City of much Splendor; ſends Burgeſſes to Parliament, Gives Title to the Right Noble Henry Marqueſs and Earl of WORCESTER: Is an Epiſcopal See Numbering 88 Biſhops ſucceſſively: Is Govern'd by a Mayor, &c. Is Divided into 7 Wards, accounting in all, beſides the Cathedral, 11 Pariſh Churches, has 3 Grammer Schools and 7 Hoſpitals; Drives a great Trade in Clothing, which Company being Conſtituted of Weavers and Walkers are Incorporated and Confirm'd by Act of Parliament; who either of Lemſter Ore or Spaniſh Wool make the moſt and Fineſt Cloth in England: and has 3 Markets Weekly.
You croſs the foreſaid Severn and Enter St. Johns, that part of the Suburbs ſo call'd, of 3 Furlongs Extent.
You croſs the ſmall River Laughern.
Cotheridge Church appears 2 Furlongs on the Left.
Enter Broadwaies, a ſcattering Village of 2 Furlongs
Todnam Chapel contiguous on the Right

Over a Wood-bridg you croſs the Temde or Teme, which riſing on the Edg of Radnorſhire, paſſes by Knighton, Ludlow and Tenbury; and about two Miles below this place falls into the Severn: Receiving into it, 1ſt. the Bradfield; 2ly. the Clune, and therein the Onke; 3ly. the Ony, and therewith the Warren and Bow, Stadbrook and Quenny; 4ly. the Corve; 5ly. the Ledwich; 6ly. the Rea.
Lulſey Church lies a little diſtant on the Left.
Enter Herefordſhire at a little Rill.
You have Houſes ſcattering on the Road.
Enter Bromyard Heath 5 Furlongs over.
Over a Stone-bridg of 2 Arches you croſs the Froom and preſently Enter Bramyard alias Bromiard, of 4 Furl. a large well Accomodated and well frequented Market-Town.
You come to Birdonbury, a ſmall diſcontinued Village.
Enter Hockly, a long ſcattering Village.
You come to Stein Bridg over a Brook.
You paſs by Eaton a ſmall Village contiguous on the Left.

Over a Stone-bridg of 3 Arches you
croſs the Lug, and afterward 2 Brooks ſucceſſively.

Enter Leominſter vulgo Lemſter, only of 4 Furlongs this Way, but a Mile tranſverſe; a large well built and well Accomodated Corporation and Market-Town of about 400 Houſes, Divided into 6 Wards; Govern'd by a Bailiff, &c. Elects Parliament Men, and is Eminent for its Fine Wool call'd Lemſter Ore.
You leave Kingſland Church a Furl. on the Right.
You croſs the ſmall River Oncy, and preſently enter Kingſland a diſcontinued Village of 4 Furlongs.
You come to Eaſterton a ſmall Village of near 2 Furlongs.
You deſcend 2 Furlongs.
You have two or three Houſes on the Road and Hills on your Left.
You croſs the ſmall River Wadels, and enter Comb a ſmall Village of about a Furlong.

You enter Radnorſhire, and a Furl. beyond, Preſtain, Seated on the River Lug, of 4 Furlongs Extent, large, well Built, and well Accomodated; the Shire-Town, enjoying a good Market, and a good Trade in Mault.
Enter Diſcoyd a ſcattering Village of 2 Furlongs.
You paſs by Caſcob a ſmall Village, 2 Furl. farther aſcending a Hill of 6 Furl.
You have Blethuagh Foreſt on the Right.
You deſcend 7 Furlongs, leaving Blethuagh Church near a Mile on the Right.
You aſcend 5 Furlongs, deſcending 4.
You paſs by 2 or 3 Houſes on the Road.
You croſs the ſmall River Comaron, aſcending 4 Furlongs.
You deſcend 4 Furlongs.
You croſs the River Ithon, falling into the Wye above Bealt.
You croſs Clowedok fluv. falling into the foreſaid Ithon.
You paſs over a little Hill.
You aſcend a Hill of 4 Furlongs.
You deſcend 6 Furlongs.
You croſs the ſmall River Dulas.

Enter Riadergowy vulgo Rathader, o • 3 Furlongs Extent; Seated on the Rive •
Wye, but in a Mountainous Part of th • Country, whereby 'tis neither large no • plentifully accomodated; yet a Market Town, and Govern d by a Bailiff, &c▪
Over a Wood-bridg you croſs the Wye
You aſcend for 10 Furlongs.
You deſcend 6 Furlongs.

You aſcend 2 Furlongs, and have th • River Eland parallell to you at 2 Fu •
longs diſtance on the Left.

Croſſing Ecomiſtwith Brook, you enter Cardiganſhire, and aſcend for 6 Fu •
longs, equally deſcending.
You paſs by the Lead-Mines, and 3 Furlongs farther, a Houſe call'd Mowen-Glowth on the Right; a Woody Deſcent of 7 Furlongs conveying you to Brunant.
You paſs through Brunant a ſmall Village.
You have 3 or 4 Houſes on the Left, and you aſcend for 10 Furlongs.
You touch upon the River Rydal on the Right.
You deſcend for 12 Furlongs.
You croſs the River Rydal, and two Furlongs beyond enter Llanbadern-Vawr, of 6 Furlongs Extent, well Built, with a fair Church, formerly an Epiſcopal See.

Enter Aberiſtwith, Seated on the Rydal near it's Confluence with the Iſtwith; a Corporation, Market and Mayor-Town, Electing one Burgeſs to Parliament; formerly Wall'd about, and ſtill ſhewing a ruinous Caſtle: Numbers near 100 Houſes; is principally frequented for it's Fiſhing Trade, and is oppoſite to Arclo in Ireland.
M. F.
A Furlong from Aberiſtwith the Left to Welſhpool.
At the End of Llanbadern-Vawr the Left to Welſhpool.
At the Top of the Hill the Right to Roſefair.
The Right-Hand Way.
Seven Furlongs ſhort of the Deſcent leading to Brunant, the Left to New-Town.
Eleven Furlongs beyond Ryadergowy, the Left to Montgomery.
Nine Furlongs ſhort of Clowedock fluv. the Left to Ludlow
A little ſhort of Ithon fluv. the Left to Knighton.
At the Foot of the Aſcent leading to Blethuagh Foreſt, the Right to Radnor.
At Caſcob the Left to Knighton.
In Diſcoyd and 3 Furlongs beyond, the Right to Keinton.
Three Furlongs beyond Preſtain, the Right to Keinton.
Two Furlongs beyond Comb, the Right to Keinton.
Three Furlongs beyond Eaſterton, the Right to Arland.
In Kingſland the Left-Hand Way.
Two Furlongs beyond Kingſland, the Right to Lawton.
A Mile ſhort of Lemſter the Right to Evington.
In Lemſter the Right to HEREFORD.
Four Furlongs beyond Lug Bridg, the Right to Hampton, and a Furlong beyond, the Left to Pidleſton.
Againſt Cotheridg Church the L. to Hallow
Six Furlongs beyond WORCESTER, the Left to Eveſholm.
At the End of Stouton, the forward Way on the Right to Ʋpton.
At the End of the Common 14 Furlongs ſhort of Perſhore, the Left to Aulceſter.
Three Furlongs beyond Perſhore Bridg, the Left to Eveſholm.
In the Vale of Eveſholm, 2 Miles ſhort of Wickenford Bridg, the Right to Winchcomb.
Upon Broadway Hills, 7 Furlongs ſhort of Burton's Aſh, the Right to Stow.
At the Bottom of the Hill, 10 Furl. beyond the 4 Shire-Stone, the Right to Chipping-Norton.
At the End of Enſton, the Right to Killington.
A Mile ſhort of Glimpton, the Right to Woodſtock.
In Glimpton the Left to Banbury.
Three Furlongs beyond Wotton Church, the Left-Hand Way uniting at 62′ 4.
M. F.
FIve Furlongs from OXFORD, the Left to Heddington.
Eleven Furlongs ſhort of Wheatly, the Right to Henley.
M. F.
At Foreſt-Hill the Left to Haulton.
Nine Furlongs ſhort of Wheatly Bridg, the Right to Wheatley.
Thirteen Furlongs beyond Tetſworth, the Right to Henley, the Left to Aſton.
Seven Furlongs beyond Stoken Church, the Left to Wickham the Coach-Way.
At the End of Ʋxbridg, the Left to Swakley.
Four Furlongs ſhort of Hellingdon, the Right to Colebrook.
In Hanwell the Right to Brantford.

div.head: Direct Independants. Iter II. The Road from LONDON to ARUNDEL In Suſſex.
div.p:
The General Account.
1. THE Point of Bearing
S. W. b S.
2. The Direct Horizontal Diſtance 49 M.
3. The Vulgar Computation 46 M.
4. The Dimenſuration 55′ 4.
From LONDON
Comput. Meaſure.
to Towting 05 05 06′ 7 06′ 7
Ewell
06 11 07′ 1 14′ 0
Letherhead 05 16 05′ 5 19′ 5
Darking
04 20 04′ 6 24′ 3
Stoneſtreet 05 25 05′ 5 30′ 0
Billinghurſt 10 35 11′ 3 41′ 3
Amberley 08 43 09′ 7 51′ 2
Arundel
03 46 04′ 2 55′ 4
Continued from Arundel to Chicheſter 10′ 4.
Midleſex, Surrey and Suſſex include the Road; the Thames, Mole, Oke, Arun and Lavant, are the Principal Rivers Croſt over.

* Note, there are different Ways to Arundel, for ſome will paſs by Horſham, others again more frequently by
Stretham, Micham and Sutton, and ſo to Darking.

row.cell: M. F.
AT the End of Newington, the Right to Kingſton.
At the Gallows the Left to Croydon.
A Furlong beyond Martin Abby, the forward Way on the Right to Kingſton.
Five Furlongs ſhort of Ewell the Left to Nonſuch.
In Ebbeſham the Right to the Common.
In Letherhead the Right to Guilford.
In Darking the Right to Guilford.
At the Entring Suſſex, the Left along Honey Lane uniting again; and 4 Furl. beyond, the Right to Guilford.
Two Furlongs ſhort of Rohook the Left to Horſham, and 3 Furlongs farther, the Left by Screw Bridg uniting again.
A Furlong beyond Amberley the Left.
Six Furlongs beyond Houghton the R. to CHICHESTER.
M. F.
THe Standard in Cornhil, whence you proceed along Gracechurch-ſtreet, Fiſh-ſtreet-Hill, over London-Bridg, and through Long Southwark.
You leave the Town.
Enter Newington a Village of 2 Furlongs Extent.
Leave the Gallows on the Right, the Place of Execution of Malefactors within the County of Surrey, Convicted at Southwark.
You paſs over Clapham Heath.
Enter Towting-beck, a ſmall Village of 2 Furlongs.
Enter Towting-Graveney another ſmall Village of 2 Furlongs.
You croſs a ſmall Rill, paſſing afterwards by Martin Abby on the Left.
Enter Moredon a little Village of a Furlong.
Leave Noneſuch 2 Furlongs on the Left, a ſtately Houſe of the King's, Built by H. 8.
Enter Ewell a ſmall Market-Town of 2 Furlongs.
Enter Ebbeſham vulgo Epſom well-frequented for it's Medicinal Waters.
Epſom Well lies 3 Furlongs to the Right.
Enter Leatherhead a Town of 3 Furlongs and good Reception.
Enter Mickleham a Village of 2 Furlongs.
You croſs the River Mole near the Place where it makes a ſubterranean Paſſage for a Mile or two.
Enter Darking or Darkin, Situate on a Branch of the Mole, a large, well frequented and well-accomodated Market-Town, extending principally towards Guilford on the Right.
You aſcend for 2 Furlongs, equally deſcending.
Aſcend again 3 Furlongs, your Road Woody on each Hand.
Aſcend Cold Harbor Hill 3 Furlongs, deſcending 6 Furlongs.
Enter Stone-ſtreet alias Stanſtreet, a ſcattering Village of 3 Furlongs; whence you have a Cauſeway of 2 Miles, part of the old Roman Port-way, call'd Stany-ſtreet.
You deſcend 2 Furlongs, and come to Okewood Bridg over the River Oke, equally aſcending Okewood Hill.
Having from London-Bridg hitherto been in Surrey (an Earldom in the Perſon of Thomas Howard Duke of Norfolk) you enter Suſſex.
You come to Rohook a ſmall Village contiguous on the Right.
You enter a Wood of 3 or 4 Furlongs.

You croſs the River Arun, leaving Detſum Place 2 Furlongs on the Left between this and the other Way by Screw-Bridg; the Left-Hand Ways hereabouts lead to that handſom Corporation, Market & Shire Town, Horſham, about 2 Miles diſtant.
You come to Buckman-Corn, 2 or 3 Houſes ſo call'd.
Enter Billinghurſt of 3 Furlongs and good Accomodation.
You paſs through Mulſey a little diſcontinued Village, and 2 Furlongs farther over New-Bridg.
You paſs over Pulborow Common.
Deſcend for 3 Furlongs.
You come to Wickford Bridg, leaving Pulborow Church a Mile on the Right.

Enter Wickenholt a Village of a Furl. length; 2 Furlongs beyond which begins Parham Park contiguous on the Left, extending 11 Furlongs, and encloſing near the farther End the Place or Manor-Houſe of the ſame Name.
You paſs through Parham a ſmall ſcattering Village; whence you have a deſcent of 2 Furlongs, ſeconded by 2 others of the like quantity.
Enter Amberley an indifferent Thorough-fare of 3 Furlongs.
Over Houghton Bridg you croſs the Arun, continuing thence on your Left to Arundel.
Enter Houghton a Village of 2 Furl.
You aſcend for 3 Furlongs.

Enter Arundel by the Way of Mary-Gate, about 6 Furlongs long; an Antient, well-frequented and accomodated Corporation, Market and Seaport-Town, Seated on the N. W. of the River Arun, and having on It's Eaſt Side a large and Eminent Caſtle, on whoſe Poſſeſſion is Entail'd the Earldom of Arundel, now in the Perſon of Thomas Howard Duke of Norfolk.
M. F.
ENter the Old Fiſh-Market in Arundel, proceeding through the Water-Gate.
Begins Arundel great Park on the Right, extending 9 Furlongs.
Deſcend Amsford Hill of 4 Furlongs.
You come to Mackrel's Bridg.
You paſs by Half-way Tree.
You paſs through Crockerhil a ſmall Village.
You have Boxgrove Church and Hall a little on the Right.
You paſs through Maudlin a ſcattering Village.
You paſs between Hampnet Church on the Right, and the Place on the Left.
You croſs the Lavant.

Enter the Suburbs of CHICHESTER, antiently Ciſſanc-Caſter, Seated on the foreſaid Lavant near It's Influx into the Sea; a City indifferent large, numbring 4 Pariſh-Churches within the Walls beſides the Cathedral, and 4 Gates reſpecting the 4 Cardinal Points: Is Govern'd by a Mayor, &c. Elects Parliament-Men, and it's Markets are Noted for the beſt Fiſh-Markets in the County.
M. F.
AT the End of Maudline the Left to Petworth.
M. F.
IN Amberley the Left.
Nine Furlongs ſhort of Arun fluv. the Right by Screw-Bridg uniting at 35′ 2.
Seven Furlongs beyond Rohook the Right along Honey-Lane uniting at 32′ 7.
A Furlong beyond Darking the Right to LONDON by Stretham.
In Leatherhead the Left to Kingſton.
Entring Ewell the Left to Kingſton.

div.head: Direct Independants. Iter III. The Road from LONDON to BARWICK In Northumberland.

row.cell: 1. THE Point of Bearing
N. b. W.
2. The direct Horizontal Diſtance
3. The Vulgar Computation
4. The Dimenſuration

div.p: Counties paſt through, Midleſex, Hartfordſh. Cambridgſh. Huntingdonſh. Rutlandſh. Lincolnſh. Nottinghamſh. Yorkſh. the Biſhoprick of Durham, and Northumberland.

Rivers Croſt over are, the Lea, Granta, Owſe, Nine, Welland, Witham, Trent, Meden, Idle, Whitwater, Dun, Went, Are, Wharf, Nid, Your or Owſe, Swale, Wisk, Tees, Skern, Were, Tyne, Blith, Wanspeck, Ale, Warn, Tweed.

row.cell: M. F.
THe Standard in Cornhil, LONDON, whence you proceed along Biſhops-Gate-ſtreet within, through Biſhops-Gate, Biſhops-gate-ſtreet without, and Shoreditch.
* At Shoreditch Church the Right to Hackney.
Leave the Town, Hogſdon appearing a Furlong to the Left.
Enter Kingſland a Village of a Furlong.
** The Right to Iſtington.
Enter Newington a Village of 2 Furlongs, the Church about a Mile on the Left.
You come to a gentle Aſcent for 4 Furlongs call'd Stanford-Hill, as gently deſcending to 4′ 5.
** On Stanford Hill the Left to Hackney.
Enter Tottenham-High-Croſs of about 3 Furlongs, a Village well-frequented by Citizens.
Having firſt paſt ſeveral Houſes on the Road and the Church on the Left, you enter Tottenham-Street of near 2 Furlongs.
Enter Edmonton a long diſcontinued Village, the Church on the Left 2 Furlongs.
You come to Ponders-End a ſmall Village.
You enter Lackmore-End another Hamlet of about 2 Furlongs.
Enter Enfield-Waſh a long diſunited Village.
** In Enfield-Waſh avoid the Right.

Firſt leaving Tuttle-ſtreet on the Left half a Mile, you enter Hartfordſhire,
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
and therewith Waltham-Croſs of 3 Furl. near a Mile to the Right of which, and on the other ſide the Lea, is the Market-Town of Waltham-Abby.
Having left Theobalds a Houſe of the Kings on the Left, you come to Croſsbrook, and 2 Furlongs beyond, Turners-Hill, ſmall Villages.
** In Turner's Hill avoid the Right.
Enter Cheſton-ſtreet 2 Furl. the Church half a Mile on the Left.
Enter Wormeley-End of 2 Furlongs, the Church a quarter of a Mile on the Left.
Croſs the New River diſcourſt of in the beginning of the Road from LONDON to Holyhead.
You come to Brockton a Village of a Furlong Extent.
After an eaſie Deſcent you enter Hodſdon of above 6 Furl. Extent, Seated on the Weſt of the Lea, a well-frequented Market-Town.
* To Broctonbury-Hall.
Leave Hayley Church a little on the Left.

Enter Amwel a ſmall Village, from which and Chadwel another adjacent Village, the foreſaid New River is convey'd to LONDON. The Left-Hand Ways hereabouts lead to Hartford the Shire-Town, about 2 Miles diſtant; a Marquiſate and Earldom in the Perſon of William Seymour Duke of Somerſet.
* Avoid the Right-Hand Way.
** The Right to Hartford.

Enter Ware a Mile in Length, at the hither End whereof, you firſt croſs the ſaid New-River, and next the foreſaid Lea; for which vid. the Road from London to Harwich: The Town is large, of good Reception and a handſom Market.
You paſs by Wades-Mill, where you croſs the Mimer a Branch of the Lea.
Paſs through High-Croſs-End a ſmall Village.
After an eaſie Deſcent you paſs through Colliers-End another Village.
* The Right to Standon.
Enter Puckrich or Puckeridg of 3 Furlongs Length; a Mile to the Right of which is Standon a Market-Town.
Leaving Puckrich, the Road to Cambridg and Kings-Lyn on the Right.
Repaſs the Mimer.
You come to Buntingford a Market and good Thorough-fare Town of 3 Furlongs.
through New-Chipping a Village.
You come to Buckland another Village.

After an eaſie Deſcent you enter Royſton, Seated upon the Ermin-ſtreet, near the Edg of the County, Part of it being in Cambridgſhire; a large Town of 4 Furlongs Extent, enjoying a good Market for Corn: Here the Poſt goes off to Cambridg, &c.
Enter Cambridgſhire.
You come to Kneeſworth a Village.
Croſs the Grant or Cam which runs by Cambridg.
You come to Arrington a Village of a Furlong.
Leave Wimple a little on the Right, and at 46′ 2. Cungrave on the ſame Hand.
* The Left to Packſton.
Enter a little Wood of 4 Furlongs.
** The Right to Packſtone.
You paſs through Holm a Village.
** The Left-Hand Way to Bourn.
Enter Caxton of 3 Furlongs Length, a Market and Poſt-Town.
Enter Papworth Everard a Village of 2 Furl. and at 53′ 3. leave Neather Papworth or Papworth Agnes, about half a Mile on the Left.
Enter Huntingdonſhire.
You paſs by Beggars-Buſh, Seated on an Eminence, a Buſh ſo call'd.
After a ſmall Deſcent you enter Godmancheſter of 4 Furlongs; a Corporation large and antient; and here you have a Way to Cambridg 12 Miles off.

You croſs the River Owſe, for which (vid. LONDON to King's-Lyn) and enter Huntingdon, a well-frequented Corporation, Market and Shire-Town, containing 4 Churches, heretofore 15. Extends about 6 Furlongs on the Road;
Elects Parliament-Men, and gives Title to the Right Honorable Theophilus Haſtings Earl of Huntingdon.
* At the End of Huntingdon Leave the Right.
Enter Great Stukely a Village of 2 Furl.
Paſs through Little Stukely.
Paſs by Stonegate-Hole a Houſe on the Left; and at 65′ 0. Stonegate a Houſe on the Left alſo.
** The Left to St. Ives.
Leave St. Andrews Chapel a little on the Right.
Leave Cunnington 2 Furlongs on the Right.
Enter Stilton of 3 Furlongs Extent, a Poſt-Town.
** The Right to Oundle and the Left to PETERBOROƲGH.
You paſs between Cheſterton on the Left, and Allerton on the Right.
* A Way to Allerton.
You come to Waſhington Corner.
** The Left forward Way to PETERBOROƲGH.
Enter Water-Newton a Village of two Furlongs, Situate on the Southern Banks of the Nine.
You paſs through Sibſon a Village.
Croſs the Nine aforeſaid, and enter Northamptonſhire, and therewith, Walmsford of 2 Furlongs Extent.
** The right-forward Way to Stilton a different Way.
Leave Wittering 2 Furl. on the Left; and at 81′ 4. the Left forward.

Having firſt paſt between Wolthrop and Burleigh Halls, you enter Stamford, Seated on the Welland, and in the County of Lincoln at It's Conjunction with Rutland and Northamptonſhire; an antient, large and floriſhing Corporation and Market-Town, of 5 Furlongs Length, Electing Parliament Men; was formerly an Univerſity, and now gives Title to the Right Honorable Henry Grey Earl of Stamford.
** The Left to Ʋffington.
Enter Rutland.
** The Right or forward Way which unites again at 81′ 4.
Croſſing a ſmall Rill you enter Bridg-Caſterton of 2 Furlongs Length.
You have Tickingcote 2 Furl. on the Left; and at 89′ 6. Greetham at the like diſtance on the ſame Hand.
Paſs through a ſmall Wood.
Leave Stratton 2 Furl. on the Right.
** Oppoſite to Stratton avoid the Right, and the Left to Stratton.
Paſs through another little Wood.
Enter Lincolnſhire.
Through Poſt-Witham alias North-Witham, of 2 Furlongs; or you may leave it half a Mile on the Left.
** The Right to Buckminſter, the Left to Corbey.
Through Coltſworth a Village.
Croſs the River Witham, taking it's Riſe a Mile or two above.
* The Right to Eaſton.
You have a ſmall Deſcent and a Rill in the Bottom.
** The Right to Kirk-Stoke, the Left to Eaſton.
You come to Great Paunton a Village of near 2 Furlongs, Seated near the Witham, and of good Antiquity.
Leave Little Paunton 2 Furlongs on the Left.
** The Left to Boſton.
Paſs by the Spittle or Hospital on the Left, and a few Houſes on the Right.

Enter Grantham, Seated low, and on the Weſtern Banks of the Witham; a large and well-frequented Corporation and Market-Town of 4 Furlongs Extent, with a fair Church and good Free-School, and the Election of Parliament Men.
* The Left to Barobey.
You aſcend gently 3 Furlongs, and then croſs a ſmall Rill, paſſing between the Gallows on the Left, and a Wind-Mill on the Right.
Your Aſcent continuing hitherto, you come to Gunnerby a Village.
You deſcend Hoocliff Hill for 2 Furlongs.
Leave Allington 2 Furl. on the Left.
** The Right forward Way.
Enter Foſton of near 3 Furlongs Extent.
** The Left to Weſtburrow.
You arrive at Bennyngton a diſcontinued Village of a Mile in Length.
* The Right to Dodington.
** The Left to Dodington.
Enter Nottinghamſhire.
You come to Balderton a Village.
** Avoid the Right.

Firſt paſſing by the Gallows, avoiding the Way on the Right to Codington, you enter Newark Seated on the South-Eaſt Side of the Trent, a large, well-frequented Corporation and Market-Town of 6 Furl. in Length; hath it's Repreſentatives in Parliament, and the Ruins of a once ſtately Caſtle.
Over a fair Bridg you croſs the Trent aforeſaid.
* The Left to Kellum.
** The Right to Kellum.
You paſs a ſeparated Branch of the Trent, which uniting again, forms an Iſland of 2 Miles long, and half ſo broad.
You come to South-Muſcomb a Village.
You paſs by North-Muſcomb contiguous on the Right, Seated on the Banks of the Trent.
Enter Crumwell, on the Banks of the Trent alſo, a Village of 2 Furlongs.
You croſs a ſmall Rill falling into the adjacent Trent.
You come to Carlton upon Trent, a ſmall Village.
** The Right to Norwel.
You paſs through Sutton another ſmall Village, Seated likewiſe on the Trent, which afterwards winds off to the Right.
You paſs through Weſton a ſmall Village.
* The Right to Normanton.
** The Left to Normanton.
Enter Tuxford in the Clay of 3 Furl. Length, an indifferent Market and Poſt-Town.
Leave Little Markham 2 Furlongs on the Left.
You have a ſmall Deſcent and a Beacon on the Right.
** On the Beacon Hill avoid the Left.
You croſs the Idle falling into the Dun.
Through Weſt (or Little) Draiton a Village.
** Avoid the Right.
Croſs a ſmall Rill falling into the adjacent Idle, and enter the Foreſt of Sherwood.
* The Left to Elſey.
Leave Elſey Church a little on the Left.
Paſs by the 4 Oaks.
Leave Babworth a little on the Right, and Redford a Market-Town at about a Miles diſtance on the ſame Hand, upon the foreſaid Idle.
* The Right to Sutton, the Left acute.
Enter Barnby on the Moor, a Village of 2 Furlongs.
Through Turworth a Village, leaving Blith a Market-Town a Mile to the Left.
You come to Ravenskel a Village.
Enter Scrooby a Village of 2 Furlongs.
** Avoid the Right-Hand Way.
You croſs Whitwater Fluv. near its Conjunction with the Idle, and Enter Yorkſhire, and Bautre a ſmall Market-Town of 3 Furl. Traded unto for Millſtones, &c.
You paſs through a little Wood.
Open Way conveys you to Roſſington a Village.
* The Right to Cantley.
** In Roſſington the Right to the Church
** The Right.
Leave High Eaders 2 Furl. on the Left.
** The Left to Cantlow.
Enter Doncaſter of 5 Furlongs length, ſituate on the River Dun, an Antient, large, well-built and well frequented Corporation and Market-Town; Traded unto for Knit-Waſtcoats, Stockins, &c.
You croſs the Dun aforeſaid, falling into the Are near Snathe.
You leave Cuſworth 2 Furl. on the Left, at 157′ 2. Scausby, and at 158′ 0. Pigborn, all at the like Diſtance and on the ſame Hand.
* The Left to Scausby.
** The Right the Street Way, the Left to Adam-ſtreet.
You paſs by Robin-Hood's Well.
** The Right to Skelburrow.
Enter Wentbridg a Town of 2 Furl. in the midſt whereof you croſs the Went falling into the Dun near Snath aforeſaid.
You deſcend 2 Furlongs.
* The Right to Womerley.
You paſs through Darrington a Village.

Enter Ferrybriggs of 3 Furlongs, a Poſt Town Situate on the South Side of the broad River Are (which falls into the Owſe near Howden) paſſable by a fair Stone-Bridg, beyond which the Left-Hand Way to Boroughbridg by Abyforth and Wetherby meaſures 9 Miles leſs than that by YORK.
* The Left to Brotherton.
You leave Brotherton 2 Furlongs on the Left, and at 172′ 2. Burton a like diſtance on the ſame Hand.
* The Right to Hillum.
** The Left to Pool and a Furlong farther the Right to Burton.
You deſcend Bettereſs Hill of 2 Furl.
Enter Milford a Village of 2 Furlongs.
Firſt croſſing a Branch of the Wharf, you arrive at Sherborn 4 Furl. Long; a Market-Town, with a good Free-School, and abounding in Cherries.
You leave Barkſton, and at 178 Scarthingwel Hall, each 2 Furl. on the Right.
You arrive at Tolton vulgo Towton, a Village of 2 Furlongs, Eminent for a great Battel between the Houſes of York and Lancaſter, Anno 1461.
** The Right to Wingate.
Over a Stone-Bridg you croſs the fair River Wharf, falling into the Owſ near Cawood, and enter Tadcaſter an antient well-provided Market-Town of 3 Furl. Length, and affording plenty of Lime-Stone.
** The Right to Tadcaſter the Street-Way.
You come to Street-Houſes a Village of 2 Furlongs: whence little occurs till at
You reach Ring-Houſes a Village of near 2 Furlongs.
You have the Gallows on the Right, and a little after 2 Wind-Mills on the Right and one on the Left.
** The Right to Green-Hammerton.
You enter the Suburbs of the City of YORK.
You enter Mickle-Gate and therewith the City it ſelf; 2 Furlongs farther you come to Owſe Bridg, and at 192′ 4. you arrive at the Pavement or Midle of the City:

The Second of the Kingdom, Seated on the Navigable Your or Owſe; well-built, and Fortify'd with a Caſtle and Walls, extending each way about 12 Furl. containing within it's 4 Wards 32 Pariſh Churches and the Cathedral, a large and Magnificent Structure with a curious Chapter-Houſe: Govern'd by a Lord Mayor, 12 Aldermen, Juſtices, &c. Is repreſented by two Burgeſſes in Parliament; and gives
Title to the moſt Illuſtrious James Duke of York.
* The Left forward to LONDON.
Continuing our Dimenſuration from Mickle-Gate aforeſaid, you repeat 3 Furlongs of the Road back again.
* The Right to Popleton.
Leave Popleton 2 Furl. on the Right.
You paſs by a Blue Stone adjoyning the Road on the Right.
Leave Heſley 3 Furlongs on the Left.
** The Right to More-Monkton.
Over Skip-Bridg you croſs the Nid, falling into the Owſe a little below.
Leave Kirk-Hammerton 2 Furl. on the Left.
** The Right to Kirk-Hammerton.
Through Green-Hammerton a Village.
Leave Whixley 2 Furlongs on the Left.
Leave Little 2 Furlongs on the Right, near which the foreſaid Owſe takes Riſe, and preſently unites with the Your.
Leave Branton-Green on the Right, and at 206′ 5. Grafton on the Left, equally 2 Furlongs diſtant from the Road.
** Avoid the Right; and at 209′ 2. the Right to Wetherby.

Having firſt left Aldborough, that old Roman City 3 Furlongs on the Right, you fall in with the Road from Ferrybriggs by Wetherby aforemention'd, and enter Boroughbriggs of 3 Furlongs Length, a Corporation
and Market-Town, with the Election of Parliament Men; at the End of which you croſs the Your aforeſaid.
* The Left to Wetherby, the Right to Aldborough.
** The Left to Humberton.
You paſs through Disford a ſmall Village.
* The Left to Rippon.
In Leeming Lane you fall in with a Right-Hand Way from YORK, which coming to LONDON is your Left-Hand Way to be avoided.
* The Left to Rippon.
You enter Topcliff eminently Situate on the Banks of the Swale, a Thorough-fare of about 5 Furlongs length.
** A little beyond the Bridg avoid the Right.
Leave Newby Hall 2 Furlongs on the Left.
Enter Catton on the Moor a Village of near 3 Furlongs.
You leave Skipton on the Left 3 Furl. and Carleton a little diſtance on the Right.
You paſs through Sand-Heuton, leaving Thresk a Market and Burrough-Town 12 Furl. on the Right.
Leave Newſom, and 6 Furlongs beyond, Kirkby, each 2 Furlongs on the Left, and upon the Banks of the Wisk.

Leave Great (or South) Ottrington, and at 226′ 3. Little Ottrington, each 2 Furlongs
on the Left, and on the foreſaid Wisk.
** The Left to Thresk.
Enter Northallerton Seated on a Branch of the Wisk, a large, well-built, Market, Borough and Poſt-Town; Electing Burgeſſes to Parliament.
** The Right to Danby.
You come to Lowſey-Hill a Village cloſe on the Left.
Enter Little Smeton of near 2 Furlongs, at the End of which you croſs the foremention'd Wisk.
You come to Great Smeton another Village.
You deſcend Break-Horſe Bank, and 4 Furlongs beyond, leave Erey Hall a little on the Left.
You paſs the Tees, enter the Biſhoprick of Durham, and therewith Nyſome a Village of near 2 Furlongs.
** The Left to Yarum.
You croſs the Skern, a little below falling into the foreſaid Tees; and enter Darlington vulgo Darnton of 5 Furl. length, a Market and Poſt-Town.
* The Left to the Coal-Pits.
** The Left to Barmetton.
You enter Coleham or Coton Mundhil, of near 2 Furlongs, Seated on the foreſaid Skern.
** Avoid the Left.
Enter Acle or Ackham a Village of near 2 Furl. alſo.
You come to Woodham a Village.

You arrive at Ruſhy Ford over a ſmall Branch of the adjacent Skern, half a Mile to the Right of which appears Windleſtone, and about 2 Miles diſtance on the ſame Hand, at the Confluence of the Gaunleſs with the Were, lies Biſhops Aukland, a Market-Town with a fair Seat of the Biſhops of Durham, curiouſly repair'd, and and a ſtately Chapel Built by the late Worthy and Reverend Father Doctor John Cozens Biſhop of Durham.
* The Left to Great Merington.
Leave Weſt Cloſe Houſe a little on the Left.
Leaving Little Chilton 2 Furlongs on the Right; you enter Ferry ſuper Montem, vulgo Ferry-Hill, a Village of 2 Furlongs, Seated on the Pitch of a Deſcent.
You come to Sunderland a Village contiguous on the Right, at the End of which you croſs the foremention'd Were.
** Avoid the Left forward.

Enter the Weſtern Suburbs of DƲRHAM, extending 5 Furlongs on the Road, the City it ſelf lying on the Right, Eminently ſituate upon (and almoſt encompaſt by) the River Were; a neat compact Place, accounting 6 Pariſh-Churches and a Cathedral: ′Tis Wall'd about, Strengthned with a Caſtle; Govern'd by a Mayor, &c. and well ſupply'd with Proviſions of all kinds.
You have the Gallows on the Left, and Cokehal on the Right.
A ſmall Aſcent conveys you to Durham Moor a Village of 2 Furlongs.
You come to Plausworth a Village contiguous on the Right.
* The Right acute.
Lumley Hall on the Right.
Enter Cheſter in the Street of 4 Furl. Extent, an antient Thorough-fare Town, Seated on the Weſtern Banks of the Were, and upon the old Roman Street-Way.
Leave Peloo Hall, and at 271 Miles, Birtley, each 2 Furlongs on the Right.
You leave the Beacon; and at 274′ 5. a Wind-Mill, both on the Right.
** The Right to Redhough.

You enter Gateſhead vulgo Gateſide, joyn'd to New-Caſtle by a ſtately Stone-Bridg over the Navigable Tine; having paſt which, you enter Northumberland, and withall, New-Caſtle upon Tine: A Town and County as well as the Shire-Town, large, ſtrong, Rich and Populous; driving a great Trade by Sea and Land, eſpecially in Coals: Is Govern'd by a Mayor, &c. Sends Burgeſſes to Parliament; hath 2 great Markets Weekly, and gives Title to His Grace, William Cavendiſh, Duke, Marqueſs and Earl of New-Caſtle.
You leave the Town.
Leave Old Heton, and at 278′ 6. Great Bentham, each about a quarter of a Mile on the Right.
Enter North-Gosford a Village of 2 Furlongs.

Having before paſt between Bladedon and Shotton, you come to Blith-Bridg over the River Blith, which riſing about 5 Miles higher, receives the Pont (from the Picts Wall) a little above this Place, and at Blith's Newk falls into the Sea.
Enter Stannington a Village of 2 Furlongs Extent.
Leave Catchborn Caſtle a little on the Left.
** The Left to Shields.

Enter Wanspeck, Seated on the River Wanspeck, which (riſing about 8 Miles higher) receives the Font a little above this Place, and 5 Miles lower falls into the Sea; over which a Stone-Bridg leads you into Morpeth, a Corporation, Market and Poſt-Town, of 4 Furlongs Extent; Elects Parliament Men, &c.
Leave the Town.
You leave Heborn, and at 295′ 0. Espeley, each half a Mile on the Left, and croſs the ſmall River Line.
* The Left acute.

Enter Cocket a Village of 2 Furlongs, at the End of which, over Felton-Bridg, you croſs the River Cocket, which riſing on the Borders of Scotland, receives the Ʋſway,
Ridley and Ridland, embracing the Sea near Cocket Iſland.
Enter Felton a Village of 2 Furlongs.
Leave Acton 2 Furl. on the Right.
You come to Newton on the Moor a Village contiguous on the Left.
You paſs through a ſmall Wood and over a Rill or two.
** Avoid the Left.
Enter Alnwick of 2 Furlongs Extent, Seated on the South Side of the River Alne; a Market-Town, ſhewing the Remains of a once large Caſtle and Abby.
You croſs the Alne, riſing about 10 Miles Eaſtward, and falling into the Sea at Aylmouth about 5 Miles below.
You deſcend 2 Furlongs.
** Avoid the Right.
You deſcend again the like quantity.
* The Left acute.
** Avoid the Left.
You come to Carleton a Village.
* The Left acute.
** Leave the Right.
Enter Warnford a Village of 2 Furlongs, Seated near the ſmall River Warne, four Miles from it's Influx into the Sea.
Leave Edderſton a Furl. on the Right.
* The Right acute.
You leave Mowſewel 2 Furlongs on the Left.
Leave Newland 2 Furlongs on the Right.
Enter Belford a Poſt-Town of reaſonable Reception.
You leave the Chapel a Furlong on the Left.
You leave Midleton about 3 Furlongs; and at 327′ 6. Detcham 2 Furlongs on the Left.
You come to Buckton a Village contiguous on the Right, 12 Furlongs diſtant from the Sea, and oppoſite to Holy Iſland.
Leave Fennick a Village 2 Furlongs on the Left.
* The Right acute.
Enter Haggerſton a Village of 2 Furl.
Leave Broom-Houſe, and at 333 Miles Bridg-Mill, each a ſmall diſtance on the Left.
You leave Cheſwick, and at 335′ 6. Skrimerſton, each about 3 Furlongs on the Left, and a Mile from the Sea Side.
* The Left acute.
You enter Twedemouth a Village of 2 Furlongs.
** The Right to Cailſho and Jedbrough, and ſo to CARLISLE.

You come to Barwick Bridg over the fair and Navigable Tweed, which riſing in Scotland, receives One and Twenty Rivers or Prime Branches, and about fifteen Miles higher becoming the Limits of the two Kingdoms, diſchargeth it ſelf into the Seat at this Place.

Enter Barwick, or Berwick, a Town
and County of great Strength, Naturally Fortify'd by the Sea and River Tweed, and Artificially by a Wall and Caſtle; Is a large, Populous, and well-built Corporation and Market-Town; Electing Parliament Men, and well ſerv'd with all ſorts of Proviſions.

div.head: Direct Independants. Iter IV. The Road from LONDON to BRISTOL.

row.cell: 1. THE Point of Bearing
W. b. N.
2. The Direct Horizontal Diſtance
3. The Vulgar Computation
4. The Dimenſuration

div.p: Counties Paſs'd through are, Midleſex, Buckinghamſhire, Barkſh. Wiltſh. Gloceſterſh. and Somerſetſh.
Rivers Croſs'd over are, the Brent, Coln, Thames, Kennet and Avon.

row.cell: M. F.

THE Standard in Cornhil, whence you proceed through Cornhil, the Poultry, Cheapſide, St. Pauls Church-Yard, Lud-Gate Street, Ludgate, down Lud-Gate Hill, through Fleet-Street, Temple-Bar, the Strand, the Hay-Market, and Pickadilly.
Begins St. James's Park Wall on the Left.
The Buildings terminate on the Right.
Over a Stone-Bridg you paſs a Rill ſupplying the Cana'l in St. James's Park.
You leave St. James's Park aforeſaid, by the Side whereof, the Way to Weſtminſter by St. James's-Street, Petty-France, and Tuttle-Street turns down on the Left, and Hide-Park begins on the Right.
You come to Knightsbridg a ſmall Village.
Hide-Park terminates, where entring Kenſington a Village of 2 Furlongs, you paſs by the preſent Lord Keepers Houſe on the Right; and paſſing the Church, at the other End of the Town Campden-Houſe.
Leave the Earl of Holland's Houſe 2 Furlongs on the Right.
Enter Hamerſmith of 5 Furlongs Extent, Seated near the Banks of the Thames; in the Summer poſſeſt chiefly by the Gentry and Citizens.
Leave Cheſwick 3 Furlongs on the Left.
You come to Turnham Green, paſſing the Wind-Mill on the Right, and the Houſes on the Left, you have at the farther End, the Seats of the Marqueſs of Worceſter and Lord Crofts.
You paſs by a fair Seat of Sr. John Mainards a Furl. on the Right.
Enter Old Brentford, ſituate on the very Brink of the Thames, and extending 4 Furlongs.

Enter New Brentford of 4 Furlongs like
wiſe; a good Market-Town, at the End of which you croſs the Brent, riſing about Edgworth towards Hartfordſhire, and here embracing the Thames.
You leave the ſtately Sion-Houſe, and at 10′ 7. Iſtleworth Church, each 2 Furl. on the Left.
You come to Small-beer Green.
Enter Hounſlow of 4 Furl. length, a well-accomodated Thorough-fare.
* At the End of the Town, the Left or forward Way leads to Stanes.

You enter Hounſlow Heath, diſtinguiſh'd into one, two, and three Mile Heaths; leaving Harlington about half a Mile on the Right, giving Title to the Right Honorable Henry Bennet, Earl of Arlington, &c.
You come to Longford a Village of 4 Furlongs, and croſs 4 ſeparated Branches of the Coln, and among them, the Cut that ſupplies the Cana'l at Hampton Court.

You croſs the Coln, which riſing about the Hempſteds in Hartfordſhire, receives the Ver (from Verulam by St. Albans) at Rickmanſworth; when limiting Midleſex from Buckinghamſhire; It paſſes by Ʋxbridg and this Place, and a little above Stanes falls into the Thames. Here you enter Colnbrook of near 4 Furlongs, a Market-Town, full of Inns, and of very good Reception.

* The Way on the Left is the Way by Datchet-Ferry to Windſor; Dignify'd with a ſtately Caſtle, the Kings Pallace, St. George's Chapel, a College, &c. and here is kept the ſplendid Feaſt at the Inſtallation of Knights of the Garter.
You leave Ʋpton 2 Furlongs on the Left.
You come to Slow, a Village with ſome Inns, in which the Road to Windſor, by Eaton College, turns down on the Left.

Having firſt paſt by Burnham, Hicham, and Toplar Churches ſucceſſively, about 3 Furl. diſtance; leave Sr. Denis Hamptons Houſe on the Right alſo, and over a fair Wooden-Bridg croſs the Thames and enter Barkſhire, an Earldom in the Perſon of Charles Howard Earl of Barkſhire.
Enter Maidenhead of 4 Furl. length, a very conſiderable Market-Town for Corn, &c.
* The great Road to Gloceſter by Henley, &c. bears forward to the Right.
You enter Maidenhead-Thicket.
** An obtuſe Way from Merloe falls in on the Right.
You come to Harehatch a Village.
* The acute Way on the Right leads to Wargrave.
Enter Twiford a Village of 2 Furlongs and good Accomodation.

You croſs the Loddon, which riſing in Hampſhire, receives the Ditford, and dividing
it ſelf here into 4 Branches, falls into the Thames about 2 Miles below.
* The acute Way on the Right leads to Sunning, a Market-Town about a Mile diſtant.
** Falls in an obtuſe Way on the Left from Ockingham, another Market-Town, about 4 Miles diſtant.
You come to Reading, Seated on the Kennet, near It's Conflux with the Thames; a fair Corporation and Market-Town, of 5 Furlongs Extent, with 3 Churches, and the Election of Parliament Men.
* Upon Tyleherſt Heath you omit the acute Way on the Right.
** An obtuſe Way falls in on the Right.
You enter Theal, i. e. The Vale, a ſcattering Town of 3 Furlongs; at the End of which you leave Inglefield, the Seat of the Marqueſs of Wincheſter, half a Mile on the Right.
Deſcend a little Hill, and enter Woolhampton vulgo Wollington, a Village of 2 Furlongs.
Enter Thatcham of 3 Furlongs.
You have the Kennet cloſe on the Left.

Enter Spinhamland, that Part of Newbury ſo call'd; whence a fair Street on the Left leads to Newbury, pleaſantly Seated on the foreſaid Kennet; a Corporation and Market-Town, with a Free-School, 3 Alms-Houſes, and an Hoſpital.

You come to Spein a Village contiguous
on the Left, aſcending gently, two Furlongs.
You have Craven Park on the Left, and Wickham Heath or Common on the Right.
You deſcend 3 Furlongs.
* The forward Way proceeds directly to Hungerford.
You paſs through a ſmall Wood.
Enter Wiltſhire.
* The forward, or Right-Hand Way leads to Lamborn.
You come to Chilton a diſcontinued Town of 4 Furlongs.
You leave Littlecote Houſe 3 Furlongs on the Left, on the other ſide of the Kennet.
Enter Ramesbury a ſcattering Town of 4 Furlongs.
You paſs cloſe by Ramesbury Manor, the Earl of Pembroke's, on the Left; where you aſcend gently 2 Furlongs, equally deſcending.
* The acute Way on the left yields a different Road to Marlborough.
You have a ſmall Wood on your Right.
You aſcend 2 Furlongs and a Chalk-Hill; at 73′ 1. paſſing through Woody Land, deſcend again.
Enter Mildenhal a Village.
** An obtuſe Way on the Right falls in from OXFORD.

By riſing Ground enter Marlborough,
2 Furl. more bringing you to the Market-Houſe, where comes in the Coach-Way to BATH, and the Way by Hungerford; extending in the Whole 6 Furlongs: A Corporation and Market-Town, Electing Burgeſſes to Parliament; and giving Title to the Right Honorable William Ley, Earl of Marlborough.
But proſecuting the directer Way by Hungerford, from 62′ 2.
You croſs the Kennet, and at once enter Wiltſhire and Charnam-Street, that Part of Hungerford ſo call'd; the Town it ſelf extending 4 Furlongs on the Left; a Market and Poſt-Town.
* You have an acute Way on the Right to Froxfield and Ramesbury.
You have Froxfield Church on the Right 2 Furlongs.
You enter Savernake Foreſt.
You aſcend eaſily 7 Furlongs; and at 72′ 6. deſcend again 2 Furlongs.
You croſs the Kennet and enter Marlborough; 2 Furl. more bringing you to the Market-Houſe and Croſs-Way aforeſaid; ſo that this Way is leſs by 11 Furlongs than by Ramesbury: But proceeding,
Accounted by Ramesbury, you leave Marlborough and the Duke of Somerſet's Houſe and Mount on the Left.
You leave Preſhuter Church, and afterwards Manton and Clatford about 2 Furlongs on the Left, all beyond the River.
You Leave Fifield 2 Furlongs on the ſame Hand, on this ſide the Kennet.
You deſcend 2 Furlongs.
(Having aſcended 2 Furlongs) you deſcend the like quantity.
You come to Little Kennet a Village.
* You Ride cloſe under Sidbury Hill, an artificial Mount; where the Road to the Devizes branches out on the Left.
You come to Beckhampton vulgo Beckington, a Village.
* Being entred Marlbrough Downs, the Road to BATH by Sandy Lane, bears forward on the Left.
Having paſt two Aſcents and one Deſcent, you leave Cheril a Furlong on the Right.
You come to Cumberford Bridg over the River Coln.
Enter Caln, Seated on the foreſaid Coln, of 5 Furlongs extent; a Market-Town, with the Election of Parliament Men; towards the farther End of which, the forward Way on the Right leads to Malmſbury.
You come to Studley Bridg over the foreſaid Coln; whence you aſcend 3 Furlongs.
You come to Studley a Village.
** An obtuſe Way from the Devizes falls in on the Left, where you deſcend 2 Furlongs.

Enter Chipenham, of 7 Furlongs length,
Seated on the Avon, which you croſs in the Town over a fair Stone-Bridg; a Market-Town, with the Election of Members to Parliament.
* A little beyond the Bridg, the Road to BATH by Pickwick, &c. turns out on the Left.
* The Right-Hand Way leads to Sodbury, and thence over into Wales by Auſt-Ferry.
You deſcend 3 Furlongs, and at 98′ 7. aſcend alike, leaving Caſtle-Comb a Market-Town, about 2 Miles on the Right.
Wraxhal Church cloſe on the Right.
Enter Gloceſterſhire.
Enter Marſhfield 4 Furlongs in length, bleakly ſituate on the Wolds, with a great Corn-Market.
Cold Aſton Church 2 Furlongs on the Left.
You deſcend Tug-Hill of 3 Furlongs.
** The Plough-Way falls in on the Right.
** A Road from BATH falls in on the Left
You aſcend 3 Furlongs deſcending alike.
** An obtuſe Way from Deinton falls in on the Right.
Aſcend Barton Hill for 6 Furlongs, paſſing through Kingſwood and by the Coal-Pits.
You come to Dungeon Croſs.

** An obtuſe Way from Stapleton falls
in on the Right, where you enter the Suburbs of the City of BRISTOL.
** The Road from GLOCESTER falls in on the Right, and you arrive at Lawfords-Gate, whence through Lawfords Street, Caſtle-Gate, and Vine-Street, you Meaſure 115′ 2. to the High-Croſs of the City.

BRISTOL, a City and County, Seated on the River Avon; large, Populous and well Built, eſteemed the Second of the Kingdom for Trade and Traffique; contains 18 Pariſh-Churches beſides the Cathedral; made an Epiſcopal See by King H. 8. Wall'd about; Govern'd by a Mayor, &c. Sends Burgeſſes to Parliament; and gives Title to the Right Honorable George Digby Earl of Briſtol.
